unnormalised: The monsoon had just begun its annual onslaught on Mumbai. The air hung thick with humidity, and the usual cacophony of the city was punctuated by the rhythmic drumming of rain on corrugated iron roofs. I remember reading in the newspaper just yesterday, maybe the 17th of July 2023, about the BMC's (Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation) preparedness for the season, especially regarding waterborne diseases. They claimed to have stocked up on medicines and planned extensive public awareness campaigns. It all sounded reassuring on paper.

They claimed to have stocked up on medicines and planned extensive public awareness campaigns. It all sounded reassuring on paper.

unnormalised: My mother, a retired school teacher from Dadar, however, wasn't convinced. "These promises, beta, they make them every year. But when the time comes…," she'd grumbled, stirring her morning chai. Her words, as usual, proved prophetic. Within a week, the local clinic, "Dr. Patil's Clinic", was overflowing with patients complaining of fever, vomiting, and fatigue. The doctor, a harried-looking man in his late 50s, confirmed our worst fears: a surge in cases of dengue and gastroenteritis. He even mentioned, almost in passing, that a suspected case of leptospirosis had been reported at KEM Hospital.

unnormalised: Our chawl, like many others in Mumbai, wasn't exactly a model of hygiene. Stagnant water collected in every conceivable nook and cranny – discarded tires, broken flowerpots, even coconut shells left carelessly in the yard. The perfect breeding ground for mosquitoes and other disease-carrying vectors. The municipal workers, bless their hearts, did their best, fogging the area with insecticide every few days. But it felt like a temporary solution, a band-aid on a gaping wound. I often wondered if the fogging actually did any good at all. Maybe it’s only a placebo.

unnormalised: The situation escalated rapidly. More and more people fell ill, including little Rohan, the son of our neighbor, Savita bai. He was diagnosed with dengue fever, his platelet count plummeting to dangerously low levels. Savita bai, a single mother working as a domestic help, was beside herself with worry. "Rs. 10,000 a day for the hospital bed, bhai! Where will I get that kind of money?" she cried, her eyes red-rimmed. The cost of healthcare, even in a public hospital, was exorbitant for someone like her.

unnormalised: The local corporator, Mr. Sharma, finally paid a visit to our area after persistent complaints. He arrived in a gleaming white car, accompanied by a gaggle of journalists and party workers. He made a grand show of inspecting the drains, promising immediate action. "We will sanitize the entire area within 48 hrs!" he declared, for the benefit of the cameras. I remained skeptical. This wasn't the first time we had heard such promises, only to be disappointed later. It was usually a long process.

unnormalised: Later that evening, I found myself discussing the situation with Mr. Iyer, a retired civil servant who lived on the first floor of our building. "Public health, my boy," he said, shaking his head sadly, "it's not just about doctors and hospitals. It's about sanitation, awareness, and, most importantly, political will. Unless we address the root causes, these outbreaks will continue to plague us year after year." He was right, of course. The problem wasn't just the monsoon or the mosquitoes. It was the lack of infrastructure, the inadequate sanitation facilities, and the apathy of the authorities. It requires proper planning for years, and awareness among the citizens.

unnormalised: I decided to take matters into my own hands. I organized a small group of volunteers from our chawl to clean up the area, removing stagnant water and educating our neighbors about preventive measures. We distributed pamphlets on mosquito control, emphasizing the importance of keeping our surroundings clean. It was a small effort, I know, but it was a start. Maybe, just maybe, we could make a difference, one clean drain at a time. I even emailed some local NGOs to check if they could help us with mosquito nets for each of the residents, or provide basic medicines such as paracetamol 650 mg.
